title: Roll of Two Dice
question_text: Two friends are playing a board game. One friend decides to find the mean of the sum of his last three rolls. His $3$ rolls are shown below: $3$ Rolls: $8, 7, 6$ for a mean sum of $7$ . Is this friend's next three rolls guaranteed to be equal to $7$ ?

choices.text: No, because rolling 2 2 dice produces random sums
No, because 8 , 7 8 , 7 & 6 6 have been rolled and can't be rolled again
No, because a sum of 7 7 has a probability of 1 6 1 6 , so it won't happen for 5 5 more turns
Yes, because the mean will always be 7 7 as it's the most likely outcome
Yes, because we divide by 3 3 the mean will always be 7 7

solution:
Since rolling two dice represent a chance model, the sum produced when rolling two dice will be random on each turn. For example, since each number on each die has a 1 6 1 6 probability of showing on each roll, each sum has it's own probability. Therefore the sums will not always average out to be 7 7 .

The players next roll is not guaranteed to have an average of 7 7 , and in fact can be any number from 2 − 12 2 − 12 .

Choice 'A' is correct.
